review.title: Generating Sentence Planning Variations for Story Telling
review.abstract: There has been a recent explosion in applications for dialogue interaction ranging from direction-giving and tourist information to interactive story systems. Yet the natural language generation (NLG) component for many of these systems remains largely handcrafted. This limitation greatly restricts the range of applications; it also means that it is impossible to take advantage of recent work in expressive and statistical language generation that can dynamically and automatically produce a large number of variations of given content. We propose that a solution to this problem lies in new methods for developing language generation resources. We describe the ES-Translator, a computational language generator that has previously been applied only to fables, and quantitatively evaluate the domain independence of the EST by applying it to personal narratives from weblogs. We then take advantage of recent work on language generation to create a parameterized sentence planner for story generation that provides aggregation operations, variations in discourse and in point of view. Finally, we present a user evaluation of different personal narrative retellings.

sections.heading: 4 Experimental Design and Results
sections.text: We perform two experiments on Mechanical Turk to test variations generated by the deaggregation and parameters of the point of view. We compare the variations with each other and with the original sentence in a story. We are also interested in identifying differences between the individual stories. In the first experiment, we show an excerpt from the original narrative and point out to the participants that "each of the following sentences could occur next in the story." We then list all variations of the following sentence with the random relationship (examples from the Startled Squirrel labeled EST 2.0 in Table 5) and classify the sentences by personal preference (in Experiment 1, we showed 7 variations where 1 is best, 7 worst; in Experiment 2, we showed 3 variations where 1 is best, 3 worst fits within the context (1 is best, 5 is worst) and in Experiment 1, we showed the sentences according to personal preference (in Experiment 1, we showed 7 is best, where 1 is worst, 3 is worst).

sections.heading: 5 Discussion and Conclusions
